Example of spatial multi-omics data (mouse brain with Parkinson’s disease)

In this tutorial, we use mouse brain slices as an example to show the basic application of MetaChat to multi-omics data of transcriptomics and metabolomics [Marco et al., 2023].

# Importing packages
import os
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import scanpy as sc
import squidpy as sq
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

import metachat as mc

# Setting your work dictionary
os.chdir("/home/Project/MetaChat_test/mouse_brain")

Data preprocessing

Preprocessing for transcriptomics data

First, we perform basic preprocessing of the transcriptome, including data transformation, highly variable genes, clustering, and reduction visualization. All processes are handled by Scanpy [F. Alexander et al., 2018] and Squidpy [Giovanni et al., 2022].

adata_RNA = sc.read_h5ad('data/multiomics_mousebrain_parkinson_RNA.h5ad')
adata_RNA

AnnData object with n_obs × n_vars = 3011 × 32285
    obs: 'in_tissue', 'array_row', 'array_col'
    var: 'gene_ids', 'feature_types', 'genome'
    uns: 'spatial'
    obsm: 'spatial'

adata_RNA.var_names_make_unique()
adata_RNA.raw = adata_RNA
sc.pp.normalize_total(adata_RNA, inplace=True)
sc.pp.log1p(adata_RNA)

adata_visual = adata_RNA.copy()
random_seed = 42
sc.pp.highly_variable_genes(adata_visual, min_mean=0.0125, max_mean=10, min_disp=0.2)
adata_visual = adata_visual[:, adata_visual.var.highly_variable]
sc.tl.pca(adata_visual, svd_solver='arpack', random_state=random_seed)
sc.pp.neighbors(adata_visual, n_neighbors=10, n_pcs=40, random_state=random_seed)
sc.tl.umap(adata_visual, random_state=random_seed)
sc.tl.leiden(adata_visual, resolution=1)
sc.pl.spatial(adata_visual, color='leiden')

By comparing with Allen Mouse Brain Atlas [Quanxin et al., 2020], we can initially get the following six basic types of organizations.

cluster_to_cell_type = {
    '0': 'Striatum dorsal region',
    '1': 'Cerebral cortex',
    '2': 'Striatum ventral region',
    '3': 'Cerebral cortex',
    '4': 'Lateral septal complex',
    '5': 'Fiber tracts',
    '6': 'Cerebral cortex',
    '7': 'Fiber tracts',
    '8': 'Cerebral cortex',
    '9': 'Cerebral cortex',
    '10': 'Striatum dorsal region',
    '11': 'Striatum ventral region',
    '12': 'Ventricular systems',
    '13': 'Cerebral cortex',
}
adata_RNA.obs['tissue_type'] = adata_visual.obs['leiden'].map(cluster_to_cell_type)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (5,5))
sq.pl.spatial_scatter(adata = adata_RNA,
                      color = "tissue_type",
                      ax = ax)
ax.set_box_aspect(1)

Preprocessing for metabolomics data

Next, metabolomic data is imported and spatial information from the transcriptomic data is assigned to the metabolome.

adata_MSI = sc.read_h5ad('data/multiomics_mousebrain_parkinson_MSI.h5ad')
adata_MSI.uns['spatial'] = adata_RNA.uns['spatial']
adata_MSI.obsm['spatial'] = adata_RNA.obsm['spatial']
adata_MSI

AnnData object with n_obs × n_vars = 3011 × 3015
    obs: 'orig.ident', 'nCount_RNA', 'nFeature_RNA'
    var: 'features'
    uns: 'spatial'
    obsm: 'spatial'

adata_MSI.var_names_make_unique()
adata_MSI.raw = adata_MSI
sc.pp.normalize_total(adata_MSI, inplace=True)

Note

The MSI annotations for the metabolome should have the HMDB ID from The Human Metabolome Database as the variable name in the adata object, due to the fact that the built-in database MetaChatDB is indexed by the HMDB ID.

Combine the transcriptomics and metabolomics data

from scipy.sparse import hstack
X_combined = hstack([adata_RNA.X, adata_MSI.X])
X_combined = X_combined.tocsr()
var_combined = pd.DataFrame({"features" : np.concatenate((np.array(adata_RNA.var_names),np.array(adata_MSI.var_names)))})
var_combined.index = var_combined["features"]
adata = sc.AnnData(X_combined, obs=adata_RNA.obs, var=var_combined)
adata.obsm = adata_RNA.obsm
adata.uns = adata_RNA.uns

MCC Inference

Import MetaChatDB

df_metasen = mc.pp.MetaChatDB(species='mouse')

See also

If you have your own metabolic-sensor database, follow the tutorial How to Build a Custom Database.

Identify long-range channels (LRC)

Next, we will see how to identify LRCs. There are two ways to do this: (i) by marker genes, as here we utilize the high expression of Mgp as a potential spatial location for blood vessels or Gfap for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF); (ii) Manual determination of LRC through user-defined regions.

Here we show the process of identifying LRC of cerebrospinal fluid.

LRC_name = "CSF"
LRC_marker_gene = "Gfap"

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (6,5))
sq.pl.spatial_scatter(adata,
                      color = [LRC_marker_gene],
                      ax = ax)
ax.set_box_aspect(1)

We can see a clear channel near the fiber tracts. Next, we select the spots with expression above the 85% quantile as candidate spots for LRC.

mc.pp.LRC_unfiltered(adata = adata,
                     LRC_name = LRC_name,
                     LRC_marker_gene = LRC_marker_gene,
                     quantile = 85)

Cells with Gfap expression above the 85% have been selected as candidates and stored in 'adata.obs['LRC_CSF_unfiltered']'.

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (6,5))
sq.pl.spatial_scatter(adata,
                      color = 'LRC_' + LRC_name + '_unfiltered',
                      ax = ax)
ax.set_box_aspect(1)

We can see that the candidate spots have a clear channel, but are accompanied by scattered dots. We identify non-elliptical LRC clusters and exclude outliers by a local density clustering algorithm. Of these, points that satisfy both density > density_cutoff and delta > delta_cutoff will be used as cluster centers (red solid line). And points with density < outlier_cutoff will be considered as outliers spots.

LRC_cluster_CSF = mc.pp.LRC_cluster(adata = adata,
                                    LRC_name = LRC_name,
                                    density_cutoff = 7,
                                    delta_cutoff = 8000,
                                    outlier_cutoff = 4.5)

Tip

This step allows you to keep adjusting the parameters (density_cutoff, delta_cutoff and outlier_cutoff) to get the best visual effect.

mc.pp.LRC_filtered(adata = adata,
                   LRC_name = LRC_name,
                   LRC_cluster = LRC_cluster_CSF)

Candidate points for CSF LRC are clustered and outliers are removed. LRC points are stored in 'adata.obs['LRC_CSF_filtered']'.

import matplotlib.colors as mcolors
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize = (6,5))
sq.pl.spatial_scatter(adata,
                      color = 'LRC_' + LRC_name + '_filtered',
                      alpha = 1,
                      ax = ax)
ax.set_box_aspect(1)

See also

If you want to use manual determination of the LRC, please see the tutorial for details.

Next, we want to compute the cost distance for this data, based on the previously identified LRCs. for the case of multiple LRC types, enter all of them together in a list, e.g. LRC_type = [“Blood”, “CSF”].

Tip

Since the coordinate scale may vary for each data, it is difficult to intuitively estimate the parameter dis_thr, which reflects the furthest distance of influence by LRC. if you set plot=True, you can clearly see for each class of each type, which spots may be affected by the LRC, and thus determine dis_thr.

For LRC_strength, this is generally an order of magnitude greater than the minimum distance between spots.

mc.pp.compute_costDistance(adata = adata,
                           LRC_type = ["CSF"],
                           dis_thr = 1000,
                           k_neighb = 5,
                           LRC_strength = 2000,
                           plot = True)

Compute spatial cost distance without long-range channel...
Compute spatial cost distance incorporating long-range channel of CSF
The points that can occur long-range communication is...

The points that can occur long-range communication is...

    For the long-range case of cluster 1...

Finished!

With the previous preparation, we can finally begin to make inferences about metabolic cellular communication.

Tip

It is better to have the same dis_thr of this function as in dis_thr in mc.pp.compute_costDistance.

mc.tl.metabolic_communication(adata = adata,
                              database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                              df_metasen = df_metasen,
                              LRC_type = ["CSF"],
                              dis_thr = 1000)
adata.write('results/inference_results.h5ad')

There are 327 pairs were found from the spatial data.

Downstream analysis

Next, based on our previously obtained inferences, we perform a series of downstream analyses and visualizations.

adata = sc.read("results/inference_results.h5ad")

Summary communication among different scales

Since we inferred the MCC signals for each metabolite-sensor pair, and we often have a need to analyze a particular metabolite and a particular metabolic pathway or custom signal set, we need to summarize the signal sets at different scales in advance.

sum_metabolites = ['HMDB0000216','HMDB0000073']

mc.tl.summary_communication(adata = adata,
                            database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                            sum_metabolites = sum_metabolites)

Note

This function supports multiple inputs summarizing signals at the same time, for example mc.tl.summary_communication(adata = adata, database_name = ‘MetaChatDB’, sum_metabolites = [‘HMDB0000216’,’HMDB0000073’], sum_metabolites = [‘HMDB0000216’,’HMDB0000073’], sum_metabolites = [‘HMDB0000216’,’HMDB0000073’])

Identifing MCC flow

mc.tl.communication_flow(adata = adata,
                         database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                         sum_metabolites = sum_metabolites,
                         k = 5)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(15,5))
mc.pl.plot_communication_flow(adata = adata, 
                              database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                              metabolite_name = 'HMDB0000073',
                              plot_method = 'grid',
                              background = 'image',
                              group_name = 'tissue_type',
                              summary = 'sender',
                              ndsize = 8,
                              scale = 0.0000000000003,
                              normalize_v_quantile = 0.995,
                              grid_density = 0.4,
                              title = 'Image',   
                              ax = ax[0])
ax[0].set_box_aspect(1)

                              database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                              metabolite_name = 'HMDB0000073',
                              plot_method = 'grid',
                              background = 'group',
                              group_name = 'tissue_type',
                              summary = 'sender',
                              ndsize = 8,
                              scale = 0.0000000000003,
                              normalize_v_quantile = 0.995,
                              grid_density = 0.4,
                              title = 'Group types',   
                              ax = ax[1])
ax[1].set_box_aspect(1)

                              database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                              metabolite_name = 'HMDB0000073',
                              plot_method = 'grid',

ax[2].set_box_aspect(1)

Constructing group-level MCC

mc.tl.communication_group(adata = adata,
                          database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                          group_name = "tissue_type",
                          sum_metabolites = sum_metabolites,
                          n_permutations = 100)

MCC remodelling in receiver cells

adata_raw = sc.read_h5ad('data/multiomics_mousebrain_parkinson_RNA.h5ad')

metabolite_name = 'HMDB0000073'
df_deg, df_yhat = mc.tl.communication_responseGenes(adata = adata,
                                                    adata_raw = adata_raw,
                                                    database_name = 'MetaChatDB',
                                                    metabolite_name = metabolite_name,
                                                    summary = 'receiver')

import pickle
deg_result = {"df_deg": df_deg, "df_yhat": df_yhat}
with open("results/responseGenes_" + metabolite_name + ".pkl", 'wb') as handle:
    pickle.dump(deg_result, handle, protocol=pickle.HIGHEST_PROTOCOL)

metabolite_name = 'HMDB0000073'
import pickle
with open("results/responseGenes_" + metabolite_name + ".pkl", 'rb') as file:
    deg_result = pickle.load(file)
df_deg = deg_result["df_deg"]
df_yhat = deg_result["df_yhat"]
df_deg_clus, df_yhat_clus = mc.tl.communication_responseGenes_cluster(df_deg.iloc[:,:3], df_yhat, deg_clustering_res=0.2)

mc.pl.plot_communication_responseGenes(df_deg = df_deg_clus,
                                       df_yhat = df_yhat_clus,
                                       top_ngene_per_cluster = 8,
                                       colormap = 'viridis',
                                       color_range = (-2,2),
                                       font_scale = 1,
                                       figsize = (10,6),
                                       return_genes = False)

df_result = mc.tl.communication_responseGenes_keggEnrich(gene_list = df_deg[df_deg['pvalue'] < 0.05].index.tolist()[:1000],
                                                         gene_sets = "KEGG_2019_Mouse",
                                                         organism = "Mouse")

df_result.to_csv("results/responseGenes_keggEnrich_" + metabolite_name + ".csv")

mc.pl.plot_communication_responseGenes_keggEnrich(df_result = df_result,
                                                  show_term_order = [1,2,6,7,9],
                                                  cmap = 'blue',
                                                  maxshow_gene = 10,
                                                  figsize = (7,5))
